column4: Maybe you are referring to sourcing a file, like a script. example:  . /path/to/script
You could also do, "source /path/to/script" and it would accomplish the same.
would that make it run in the same process as the shell itself, rather than a sub process?
and i thought i would work on the commands too. is it that it only works on scripts? like ". ./script"
No.  It's equivalent to sourcing.  You can't source a binary in that way.
ok. i know this might be a stupid question to ask. but why not
I'm not sure why you want to attempt to source a binary file.
lol. clearly i need to read more and figure out what sourcing is. but thanks.
Think of it like a method of importing the code in some other file, into the currently executing script.
It's commonly done in other scripting languages like perl, php, etc.
aah! ok. now it makes sense.
so its like sharing the environment.
thus sharing scope. Am I right?
Sort of, yes. Think of multiple scripts utilizing a common data source or library.  Sourcing is perfect for that.
got it. thanks for clearing that up.
But yes, it's also commonly used to source a common environment file.
